title: 104_hr925
content: The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise their authority to prevent any actions that would limit the use of private property without compensation. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action limits property use, reducing its value by 20% or more. If the value diminishes by over 50%, the owner can choose to sell that portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used further. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action limits property use, reducing its value by 20% or more. If the value diminishes by over 50%, the owner can choose to sell that portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used further, unless the owner refunds the compensation amount adjusted for inflation to the Treasury of the United States. The Act states that no compensation will be provided if a property use is considered a nuisance under state law or already prohibited by a local zoning ordinance. There are exceptions outlined in the Act as well. Exceptions to the Act include no compensation for agency actions aimed at preventing hazards to public health or safety, or damage to specific property. Additionally, no compensation is provided for agency actions related to the Federal navigation servitude, except for wetlands. The Act also outlines procedures for compensation. An owner seeking compensation under this Act must submit a written request to the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate with the owner to determine the compensation amount, and if an agreement is not reached within 180 days, the owner can choose to take further action. If the agency and owner do not agree on compensation within 180 days, the owner can opt for arbitration or a civil action. Arbitration procedures will follow those in title 9, US Code, and may include attorney's fees in the award. Arbitration procedures will follow those in title 9, US Code, and may include attorney's fees in the award. An owner who does not choose arbitration or receive prompt payment can seek relief in a civil action against the agency. If the owner and agency do not agree on compensation within 180 days, the owner can opt for arbitration or a civil action. In a civil action, the owner may be entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on compensation awarded. The agency must promptly pay any award made to the owner. In a civil action, the prevailing owner is entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on compensation awarded. Payments to the owner are made from the agency's annual appropriation. In a civil action, the prevailing owner is entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on compensation awarded. Payments to the owner are made from the agency's annual appropriation. Any judgment obtained by an owner in a civil action shall be paid from the agency's annual appropriation, with the possibility of seeking reimbursement from another agency if the action resulted from a requirement imposed by that agency. Insufficient funds may lead to the head of the agency transferring or reprogramming appropriated funds. The head of the agency may transfer or reprogram appropriated funds to satisfy a judgment, and if funds are insufficient, they must seek appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act by the United States is subject to the availability of appropriations. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations on property use, explaining their rights and compensation procedures under this Act. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit any right to compensation under the Constitution or other US laws. Payment of compensation does not grant the Federal Government any rights except for use limitations resulting from agency action. The term "property" in this Act refers to land and the right to use or receive water. A use of property is limited by an agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to the action. The term "agency action" includes the making of a grant to a public authority conditioned upon an action by the recipient that would constitute a limitation if done directly by the agency. The term "specified regulatory law" includes section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act of 1979, and title XII of the Food Security Act of 1985. The term "agency" is defined in section 551 of title 5, United States Code. The term "specified regulatory law" includes section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act of 1979, and title XII of the Food Security Act of 1985, as well as the Reclamation Acts for water rights. The owner's right to use or receive water is governed by the Reclamation Acts (43 U.S.C. 371 et seq.), the Federal Land Policy Management Act (43 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.), and section 6 of the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 (16 U.S.C. 1604). The term "fair market value" refers to the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and a willing seller in a competitive market, without any compulsion to buy or sell. The term "fair market value" means the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and seller in a competitive market, without any compulsion to buy or sell. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and any other territory or possession of the United States. The term "law of the State" includes the law of a political subdivision of a State. The House of Representatives passed the document on March 3, 1995, with Robin H. Carle as the Clerk.
